newsitem.title: UK: Britain's Fergie once talked of suicide - report.
newsitem.headline: Britain's Fergie once talked of suicide - report.

text.p: Britain's Duchess of York once told a confidant that she would have committed suicide but for her small daughters, Princesses Beatrice and Eugenie, the Daily Mail reported on Friday.

It quoted Dr Allan Starkie, who has written a controversial book about the flame-haired duchess, as saying she had been distraught and stranded between her husband Prince Andrew and her American financial adviser and lover John Bryan.
He said the duchess told him: "If it weren't for the children, the only answer would be to kill myself."

The duchess, now divorced from Queen Elizabeth's second son, attempted to block publication of Starkie's book "Fergie: Her Secret Life", but she gave up her legal battle when she had to put up a 500,000 pound ($814,200) surety and faced cross-examination in court.
The duchess, popularly known as "Fergie" from her maiden name Sarah Ferguson, married Andrew in 1986. The marriage broke down in 1992 and the couple divorced earlier this year.
The Daily Mail, which is serialising the book, quoted Starkie as saying the free-spending duchess was a woman "driven by fear and lust".
Starkie said he saw her transformed "into a woman no longer quite in control, drinking and smoking too much.

"At night she would down a handful of sizeable vodkas, then take to the wine. Her cigarette butts littered the house despite her desperate efforts to give up... She looked as though her soul had gone."
Starkie wrote: "The Duchess is very complicated and very wilful. But the bottom line is I feel very sorry for her and wish her well."
